dataset.title: Spatial Patterns and Determinants of Atmospheric Carbon Dioxide Concentrations in Phoenix metro area

abstract.para: The purpose of this work is to describe determinants and spatial patterns of atmospheric carbon dioxide (CO2) in Phoenix, Arizona. Specifically, we use geographic information systems (GIS) and regression-based analyses to identify the human and biological factors that contribute to spatial and temporal variations in near-surface atmospheric CO2 levels. We use these factors to create estimated surfaces of CO2 for the urban area. We validate our surfaces using independently collected records of CO2 from several monitoring stations and transects. To investigate the temporal patterns and variations of CO2, we were able to generate CO2 surfaces for the early mornings and the afternoons, and on weekdays when traffic is heavy and spatially focused and on weekends when it is lighter and more spatially dispersed. Our findings suggest there is a distinct relationship between the structure of Phoenix CO2 levels and spatial patterns of human activities and vegetation densities. Morning CO2 levels are higher than afternoon levels and correspond closely to the density of traffic, population, and employment. The spatial structure of human activity explains the pattern of CO2 better on weekdays than on weekends. CO2 surfaces reflect declining densities of human activity with distance from the city center, the pattern of irrigated agriculture in the Phoenix area, and riparian habitats on the urban fringe. Spatial and temporal patterns of CO2 are useful in understanding urban climate and ecosystem processes

keywordSet.keyword: Biogeochemical Patterns, Processes, and Human Outcomes
central arizona phoenix longterm ecological research

CAP LTER expects that any use of data from this server will be accompanied with the appropriate citations and acknowledgments.

CAP LTER encourages users to contact the original investigator responsible for the data that they are accessing. Where appropriate, researchers whose projects are integrally dependent on CAP LTER data are encouraged to consider collaboration and/or co-authorship with original investigators.
CAP LTER requests that users submit to the Center for Environmental Studies, ASU, one copy of any publication resulting from the use of data obtained from this site.
CAP LTER requests that users not redistribute data obtained from this site. However, links or references to this site may be freely posted.

purpose.para: This research is part of a larger National Science Foundation-funded effort to understand interrelationships among CO2 levels, meteorological conditions, human activity, and ecosystem processes in urban Phoenix. The ultimate goal is to produce an integrated model of CO2 patterns and processes and predict changes in this pattern with continued population growth and land use change.

section.title: Data collection
section.para: As part of the larger NSF project to study the characteristics of the CO2 dome in Phoenix, atmospheric concentrations of CO2 were measured with an InFrared gas analyzer (model LI-800; Li-Cor, Lincoln NE) along four transects on major roadways through metropolitan Phoenix on 10 14 consecutive days from 3 to 16 January, 2000. Transects 1 and 2 were chosen to bisect the urban area, north to south and east to west respectively. Transects 3 and 4 weave in and out of the urbanized area to capture CO2 processesat the urban/rural boundaries. Measurements were taken simultaneously along all four transects at 2 meters above the ground at points approximately one mile apart between the pre-dawn hours of 5:00 and 6:00 and again during the afternoon hours of 14:00 to 15:00. Idso et al. (in press) provides a more complete discussion of data collection methods. Inconsistent and erratic readings along Transect 4 led us to drop those observations from our analysis; thus we were left with morning and afternoon CO2 readings from 227 monitoring sites spread non-randomly, but covering a broad cross-section of environments, across the metropolitan area. For each site, we calculated morning and afternoon means across the 14 days (n = 14), and then on weekdays (n = 10) and weekends (n = 4) separately. Ideally, our monitoring sites would be randomly distributed across the metropolitan area. This, however, was operationally impossible given that CO2 needed to be collected at roughly the same time across all 227 sites. All sites along a given transect could be taken within an hour, and each transect was monitored simultaneously. Therefore, we assume there was a roadway effect on all transects (Idso 1998b), which we tested during our validation experiment. We separated weekday and weekend observations because intra-urban vehicular traffic is a major source of CO2 emissions and because the intensity and spatial organization of weekend and weekday traffic differs. The sheer amount of traffic along Phoenix-area thoroughfares is more than 40 percent higher on weekdays than on weekends, with Friday as the peak and Sunday as the low point. Moreover, because weekday travel is more work-oriented than weekend travel, it is more geographically concentrated in the early morning and late afternoon hours (Barber 1986). Weekend travel is less concentrated in both time and space. In a related paper characterizing urban CO2 in Phoenix, Idso et al. (in press) found that weekday CO2 levels exceed weekend levels by 30 percent in the commercial core of Phoenix but there are no weekday-weekend differences in surrounding residential areas. Independent variables for this study are population density (POP), employment density (EMP), average weekly traffic (AWT), and vegetation density (VEG). Population data were extracted from ESRI’s 1990 compiled Census data, which are based on the 1990 Census of Population (ESRI 1997). From this CD, we extracted total population for 1997 for all Census tracts in Maricopa County, Arizona. Data were converted from an ArcView© shapefile into an Arc/INFO© coverage. Employment and traffic data were obtained from the Maricopa Association of Governments (MAG). Employment data were converted from tabular form to an Arc/INFO point coverage with the total number of employees associated with each point. Average weekly traffic data were converted from MAG’s 1998 average weekly traffic map into an Arc/INFO coverage. Vegetation data were provided by the Central Arizona Phoenix - Long Term Ecological Research (CAP - LTER) project as normalized difference vegetation index (NDVI). NDVI is an indicator, with a range from 0 to 1, representing vegetation density (green leaf area, biomass, percent green cover, productivity, and photosynthetic activity). The Soil Adjusted Vegetation Index (SAVI) is often used as a measure of vegetation in a desert/urban environment to eliminate soil-induced variations in the index (Heute 1988). Since we wanted to account for differences in soil, we elected to use NDVI. Preliminary results of our analysis showed there were only minor differences between using NDVI and SAVI in our model. The NDVI were calculated in ERDAS© from a May 1998 Thematic Mapper image (cell resolution is approximately 30 meters). The ERDAS image was geographically referenced and converted into an Arc/INFO GRID format. The month of May was selected because the general consensus among the CAP - LTER scientists was that May coincided with maximum leafout and vegetation cover. May is also one of the best times of year for collection of remotely sensed data in this region because cloud cover tends to be minimal (the winter storms are gone, and the monsoon has not yet started). We do not view the differences between May and January as significant, because there is a strong spatial correlation in vegetation patterns from month to month.

section.title: Estimating a CO2 Regression Model
section.para: We first produced estimates of population, employment, traffic, and vegetation densities in a GIS by calculating the value of each independent variable surrounding each CO2 monitoring site. Lacking a generally accepted buffer size, we calculated buffers at 200, 400, 600, 800, 1000, and 1613 meters (one mile). Preliminary results of our regression model indicated that the larger buffers produced slightly stronger correlations between the independent variables and CO2 levels, but the differences were fairly small. We settled on a one-half mile buffer (807 meters) as a compromise. It is small enough to provide spatially detailed estimates of CO2 levels but large enough to produce strong relationships between the independent variables and CO2 levels. To calculate the population value (POP) for each monitoring site, we summed the total population within the buffer based on a percent area of the Census tract (Eq.1). Percent area was used because the buffer size was usually smaller in size than the underlying Census tracts. In these situations, we assumed that population was evenly distributed across the Census tract, and therefore population was estimated by multiplying the total population in the Census tract by the percent area of the buffer. POP = SUM (Ab/At * Pi) where: Ab = area of the census tract i that fell within the buffer At = total area of census tract i Pi= total population of census tract i n = total number of census tracts that intersect buffer Average weekly traffic for each CO2 monitoring site (AWT) was calculated by a percent distance of roads within the buffer, a method similar to the population value (Eq. 2). We extracted the roads that fell within the buffer and calculated the percent of the road length that fell within the buffer. The percent length was multiplied by the average weekly traffic for each road, and the total was summed. AWT = SUM(Db/Dt * Ti) where: Db = distance of road i that fell within the buffer Dt = total distance of road i Ti= total average weekly traffic on road i n = total number of roads that intersect buffer The employment value (EMP) for each CO2 monitoring site was determined by extracting all the employment points that fell within the buffer and summing the number of employees associated with these points (Eq. 3) EMP = SUM(Ei) where: Ei = the number of employees at point i n = total number of employee points that fell within the buffer The vegetation value (VEG) for each monitoring site was calculated in two steps. We first converted the grid cells into points with the NDVI value associated with each point. The points that fell within an 807-meter buffer around the monitoring site were extracted and the vegetation index for all points was summed (Eq. 4). VEG = SUM(NDVIi) where: NDVIi = the NDVI value at point i n = total number of NDVI grid points that fell within the buffer Correlation among the indicators of human activity, POP, EMP, and AWT, are moderate to high, ranging from a correlation coefficient (r) of .72 between POP and AWT to .48 between EMP and AWT. Density of all three variables is highest in the city center, but employment is more heavily concentrated there than either population or vehicular traffic. Concern about multicollinearity led us to subject the four independent variables to principal components analysis. The principal components analysis yielded two factors with eigenvalues greater than 1.0 that together accounted for over 80 percent of the spatial variation in the four independent variables. With factor loadings of .90 for AWT, .90 for POP, and .68 for EMP, Factor 1 represents an Urbanization Factor reflecting the intensity of human activity including the presence of jobs, residents, and traffic at any given location. Highest values are in the core of the metropolitan area, and they decline outward. Factor 2, a Vegetation Factor, shows more of the vegetation cover with a loading of .97 for the NDVI. Factor scores for Factor 2 are low in the highly developed Central Business District, but high in a variety of places, including irrigated agricultural fields and the riparian habitat of the Gila River on the outskirts of the metropolitan area, and well established residential neighborhoods built on irrigated citrus groves. Both sets of component scores revealed a statistically significant deviation from normality. Both had positive skewness and positive kurtosis. As a result, both were normalized with a square root transformation. Normalized scores for the urbanization and vegetation factors were then used as independent variables in a regression equation with atmospheric CO2 concentration as the dependent variable. CO2 = a + b1 Urbanization + b2 Vegetation (5) Separate regressions were run for mornings and afternoons and for weekday and weekend averages to determine the relative importance of human activity and vegetation at the different times of the day and week and to obtain the best possible predictions of CO2 levels.

section.title: Creating CO2 Surfaces
section.para: The usual strategy to display estimated spatial patterns of air pollution in the form of a contoured surface is to use simple interpolation methods to estimate levels between observation units that are small in number and highly dispersed in distribution. Regression-based mapping has improved the traditional interpolation methods by allowing independent variables to predict the concentration of the pollutants rather than estimate levels simply on the basis of nearby points. Briggs et al. (1997) demonstrated this technique with air pollution, and Blennow and Persson (1998) used a similar method for examining frost variations. Briggs et al. (1997) used least squares regression to evaluate relationships between monitored levels of NO2 and exogenous variables, including traffic volume, road type, and land use/land cover in the vicinity of monitoring sites. Model coefficients are then used in a GIS to produce highly detailed NO2 surfaces that reflect the complex nature of spatial variation in urban air pollution. We created CO2 surfaces by calculating estimated CO2 values from maps of the four independent variables across the entire urbanized region. The urbanized region was covered by one-half mile grid squares (each approximately 2,035,571 square meters) corresponding closely to the one-half mile buffer distances we created around our 277 data observation units. A value for AWT, EMP, POP, and NDVI was produced for each of the 5,167 squares. Factor score coefficients were applied to these raw values to produce scores for Factor 1 (urbanization) and Factor 2 (vegetation). Factor scores were then normalized and used as independent variables with the regression coefficients to generate predicted CO2 values for each grid square, where a map of estimated CO2 surface can be created. Separate surfaces were produced for mornings and afternoons and on weekdays and weekends producing six maps: (1) average morning, (2) average afternoon, (3) weekday morning, (4) weekend morning, (5) weekday afternoon, and (6) weekend afternoon.

section.title: CO2 Model Validation
section.para: Validation of the predicted CO2 concentrations was carried out in two ways. First, we compared the CO2 predictions to actual CO2 levels measured at four independent sites. Two sites were located within areas of highly concentrated CO2 and two outside, with each site representing either non-managed desert landscape or managed irrigated land. The problem with these sites is, unlike the 227 transects points, they are between 180 and 600 meters from major roads and thus farther from the major source of CO2 emissions. In a second and related test, we evaluated the effects of collecting the CO2 data along major urban roadways. To test for the roadway effect on our CO2 levels, we selected six sites along major roadways and included highly vegetated, desert, and urban-residential sites with each land cover type inside and outside the areas of high CO2 concentration. CO2, temperature, wind speed, and wind direction data were collected during the pre-dawn hours and afternoon hours. Data were collected on weekdays rather than weekends because we know that traffic patterns are more concentrated on weekdays. To determine the distance decay effects, data were collected adjacent to the roadway, and at 10, 20, 40, 100, and 400-meter intervals along transects that ran perpendicular to the roadway
